Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE Track 1: Crowd-sourcing neuroscience: Neural oscillations and human social dynamics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE award is partially funded by the Perception, Action, and Cognition Program, the Cognitive Neuroscience Program, and the Social Psychology Program in the Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences in the Directorate for Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences, the Research and Evaluation on Education in Science and Engineering Program in the Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings in the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, and the Control Systems Program in the Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation in the Directorate for Engineering.

The goal of the project is to understand naturalistic human social interaction, specifically in group contexts. While neuroscientists are increasingly recording from two participants concurrently, the neural basis of group dynamics remains uninvestigated. Capitalizing on the growing body of knowledge about the role of brain rhythms, the project builds on the hypothesis that one can characterize coupled neural oscillations between individuals as one candidate mechanism that tracks successful social communication in a dynamic context. This aim is pursued by using novel portable EEG technology to record brain activity from a large number of participants concurrently (between 10-20) in ecological situations, specifically a classroom. This will address the significant hardware and software challenges associated with recording data sets from groups. Moreover, the new type and amount of data will also require a novel analytic toolbox, which will form the basis of modeling multiple brains engaged in socially relevant situations.

The research will impact education and technology, and provide significant outreach opportunities. First, the key experiments will be performed in a high school classroom, in collaboration with the science teachers. As such, the project provides a new type of platform to provide hands-on STEM training. Second, the successful implementation of the wearable mobile brain EEG recording system will have significant impact on future neuroscience research, providing a valuable tool for research outside of the lab (e.g., in a crowd: theatres, schools), with populations that are otherwise difficult to reach (e.g., children, patients, the elderly). Finally, by comparing communication between people in the same room to people at a distance (e.g., MOOCs), this project contributes to issues surrounding the relevance of real-life behavioral cues to successful communication and teaching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What determines whether our communicative interactions, in pairs or groups, are successful, for example with a teacher or a colleague? When people feel ?on the same wavelength? during a communicative exchange, are their brains actually synchronized in a more formal, quantifiable sense? The overall goal of this project was to understand naturalistic human social interaction, building on the hypothesis that one can use the EEG-based measurement and characterization of synchronized neural activity as a candidate metric to understand social communication in a dynamic context. This aim was pursued by recording brain activity from a large number of participants concurrently in ecological situations - specifically in classrooms. Neural markers were sought that track successful or unsuccessful transmission of (linguistic or other) information.

The project accomplished three major goals. The first, technology-driven goal was to be able to record electrophysiological (EEG) activity simultaneously from many participants (in our case, high school students in a classroom setting), i.e. ?crowd sourcing neuroscience,? using portable EEG equipment. The second, neuroscientific goal was to test the hypothesis that the neural ?alignment? (synchronization) between students and between a teacher and students reflects how they engage with the class material and how they engage with one another. Ultimately, one would like to exploit neural synchronization as an additional (bio-)marker for social coherence and classroom engagement, in a way that can help predict academic outcomes. The third goal, an educational one, was to design and run the experiments in collaboration with the students, enabling them to run cognitive neuroscience studies by teaching them classroom material on neuroscience as well as hands-on experimental skills. 

How does the brain support real-world linguistic interactions? We first recorded simultaneous EEG from twelve high school students and their teacher during multiple classes. We focused our analyses on brain-to-brain synchrony, quantified as the inter-brain-coherence between students as they participated in regular classroom activities (listening to the teacher, engaging in group discussions, watching educational videos). Brain-to-brain synchrony across students predicted student engagement and social cohesion (both have been found critical to the student learning experience): Students who reported to be more engaged with each other and/or the teacher showed higher brain-to-brain synchrony with their peers. One possible explanation is that higher engagement is equivalent to higher attentiveness, resulting in increased entrainment of the EEG signal with the teacher?s speech signal. This is the first study to repeatedly record brain activity from multiple people simultaneously as they engage in everyday communication outside of a laboratory environment. As such, our findings provide a potentially promising new avenue for investigations into the neuroscience of real-life everyday group interactions. 

Four major papers summarize the main findings to date (in addition to numerous conference presentations and lectures where the results were shared.

1. Dikker S, Wan L, Davidesco I, Kaggen L, Oostrik M, McClintock J, Rowland J, Michalareas G, Van Bavel JJ, Ding M, Poeppel D. (2017). Brain-to-Brain Synchrony Tracks Real-World Dynamic Group Interactions in the Classroom. Current Biology 27(9):1375-1380.

2. Bevilacqua D, Davidesco I, Wan L, Oostrik M, Chaloner K, Rowland J, Ding M, Poeppel D, Dikker S. (2018) Brain-to-Brain Synchrony and Learning Outcomes Vary by Student?Teacher Dynamics: Evidence from a Real-world Classroom Electroencephalography Study. Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience. Posted Online April 30, 2018. https://doi.org/10.1162/jocn_a_01274.

3. Dikker S, Haegens S, BevilacquaD, Wan L, Davidesco I, Kaggen L, Chaloner K, McClintock J, Ding M, West T, Poeppel D. (2018) Morning brain: Real-world neural evidence that high school class times matter. Revision Under Review.

4. Dikker S, Michalareas G, Oostrik M, Serafimaki A, Kahraman HM, Struiksma ME, Poeppel D. (2018) Crowdsourcing neuroscience: brain synchrony during face-to-face interaction outside the laboratory. Revision Under Review.

Figure 1 provides a graphical summary of the experimental set-up and analysis approaches. One critical result of this work is to have provided both the hardware design and analysis pipelines to make this sort of work possible to begin with. The interest in this research is well reflected by the number of citations and lecture invitations that the research has already yielded (>50 citations of paper 1 within one year).
